awd_titl_txt: Commutative Algebra:  F-Regularity in Algebraic Geometry and Non-Commutative Algebra
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates polynomials and the geometric shapes they define, called algebraic varieties.  The problems belong to the field of mathematics called algebraic geometry.  Algebraic geometry has many applications throughout industry and national security, including to error-correcting codes, machine learning, cryptography, computer aided design, and 3D printing. Some of these applications are concerned with studying the sets where polynomials are zero module certain prime numbers, the particular focus of this project. This project is basic research into understanding the singularities of algebraic varieties defined over finite fields, including criteria for understanding how far the varieties are from being smooth, and techniques for circumventing the failure of smoothness in some cases. The project includes research designed to be student-ready to provide training for the next generation of mathematicians.

In more precise terms, the project investigates strong F-regularity in several contexts in non-commutative algebra, combinatorics, and birational algebraic geometry. It investigates whether or not, for a strongly F-regular local ring R of prime characteristic, the algebra A of R-linear endomorphisms of F*R, where F is the Frobenius map, is a non-commutative resolution of singularities in the sense of Van den Bergh. In addition, a theory of derived functors of differential operators will be investigated, with an eye toward using it to show that rings of differential operators over fields of characteristic zero can be reduced to characteristic p under some conditions. Finally, building on recent work in valuation rings, the project aspires to show that certain section rings of varieties are always finitely generated, an important step in the minimal model program in characteristic p.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Algebraic Geometry is the mathematical science of studying geometric objects defined by polynomials. Such shapes are called algebraic varieties. An example familiar to high school students is a circle (of radius 1), which can be defined by the polynomial x2 + y2  = 1. More generally, much more complicated shapes in any dimension n can be defined by one or more polynomials in n variables. For example, even shapes appearing in medical imaging or animated movies can be approximated by pasting together algebraic varieties. For this reason, algebraic geometry is an important modern subject with applications throughout science and engineering, while at the same time, it is a beautiful ancient branch of pure mathematics still containing many unsolved theoretical problems yet to find specific applications in daily life. Some modern problems, such as characterizing varieties with certain "extreme" properties over finite fields, turn out to have important applications to error-correcting codes, a central technology in our digital world.

This project investigated algebraic varieties, especially over finite fields,  with a specific focus on the singular points---meaning points where the object is not smooth but has a sharp point or crosses itself, creating a singularity. Previous research has shown that certain singularities are "mild" in the sense that we can treat them as if they are smooth; this project investigated an important class of such "mild" singularities, called F-regular singularities, which are defined over fields of prime characteristic. In addition to settling several long-standing open problems, the project also founded a new area of investigation---namely, extremal singularities--- which promises to be widely applicable in both pure and applied mathematics, and beyond. 

Under the project, over 15 publications and preprints were produced, and the groundwork laid for many more. In addition, four PhD students completed PhDs, and four more began PhDs, and four undergraduate students were trained in mathematical research by participating in REU projects funded by the project. A research community called "Women in Commutative Algebra" was founded, which trained a number of further researchers in this area. Several students who participated in the project now supervise funded projects of their own, and others have been recruited by industry (e.g. Google) because the training recieved under this project makes them exceptionally well-qualified to tackle difficult mathematical problems in our twenty-first century data-centric world.
